text: Tried to get in here because I heard they had good jerk chicken and they tried to charge us cover to get food to go. Just horrible. All I wanted was some good food not to party. They need a better system because I even called and the girl said nothing about cover. Horrible just horrible. I feel like they were discriminating against my boyfriend and I because we were young and their crowd seemed older. I am a food blogger too and I was so excited about this. Such a let down.
One of my favorite places to go. The food is always exceptional and the atmosphere is comfortable and inviting.

Neat concept. Reggae music, Jamaican food and tropical drinks.  The bar menu just seemed kind of hobbled together lacking foresight. A lot of the menu drinks were premixed I guess to save time. The bartender was nice and attentive but was unaware how to make a Jungle Bird. They were pretty busy when I went. I got jerk wings and they were OK. With so many places doing jerk chicken you would think place would be more creative with recipes. From an economists point of view I think it's noteworthy that the kitchen stays open so long think that brings people in. There was a cover, live music. The crowd had some sprinkles of old folks, tourists, some Jamaican folks, some African Americans. Randomly ran in 2 people I knew in high school.

My friends and I came here on a Friday night for a birthday celebration. $10 cover, but check Groupon before you go, they might have a deal available. The rum punch from the front bar is better than the rum punch from the back bar. The place does get packed so arrive early. There was also a live band. We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Parking is available, but you may have to drive around a bit.

The food here is absolutely amazing! We ordered the Whole Red Snapper and Jerk Chicken Wings and shared amongst the two of us. The food was more than enough, and we could barely eat it all.  The fish was beautifully prepared with a sweet/spicy tomato sauce, rice & peas, and stewed peppers and onions. OMG! So darn good! The fish was so fresh and literally melted in our mouths!  The jerk wings were in a league of their own as well. The were beautifully smoked and you could actually taste the wood flavor from the smoking process. The jerk sauce was AMAZING!!!  When I visit Chicago, this is definitely my new favorite spot!  Oh, and the Rum Punch is legit too! I'm not even a fan of sweet drinks, but this drink definitely has a kick!  Entry fee was $5, but I didn't mind because the band was awesome as well! Oh yeah, did I forget to mention the live music? I was craving live music at 10:00 pm on a Sunday night, and thanks to Yelp, I found the perfect place! They don't close until 2 a.m. on Sundays too!  The bartender, Nicole, was warm, friendly, and inviting as well. She is the  bomb.com ! I love this place. Will definitely be back when I'm in town.

The music, bands and sound system  are EXCELLENT!!   Have had the food before and it was great.  On my last visit however,  the woman working the front bar and taking food orders was very rude when I asked her a question. Actually seemed as though I was bothering her which is odd because the place was near empty.   Made me decide to not  purchase anything and take my business up the street.

One star due to lack of response & professionalism. Tried to book a party and filled out the request online via website, followed up by a personal email, then followed up by 2 phone calls and voicemails. One week later, still no response! However, whomever is behind their Facebook page makes sure to update post hourly! Finally reached out via FB and had success. I got a robotic reply back saying my request for Thursday would be OK with some of the accommodations  (my request was for Saturday, and unspecified to what accommodations). Then after they thought to check the date they reply back with oh no, its a Saturday, only the one accommodation allowed. The robotic jerk proceeds to dance around questions and when asked for a phone call from manager, "Ted no longer works here". But he is listed on the site, has a working phone number and email. Didn't even bother to offer who the new manager is, if there even is one, the way they conduct business. The robot fires back with "oh and we are booked for the date you requested." Touchè right!? You weren't just booked before I asked for a manager though. Hmm. Nice way of saying we dont want your business. Well neither do I. Im not paying a few hundred dollars to share a lounge. open to unknown patrons. Some real authentic people need to take this place over. I should of known better to go to authentic venue then deal with some wannabe rastafarians.
Came in for the first time on a groupon with my girlfriend. The place is reggae paradise, live reggae music with delicious Jerk Chicken wings, you must try the rum punch!

The Wild Hare is one of my favorite spots to go for a night out whenever I'm home in Chicago. The music is always amazing and I love their rum punch. Haven't had a chance to try the food, but I hear great things.  My favorite thing about The Wild Hare is the atmosphere. Authentic Caribbean music, live bands that play all the reggae hits, and everyone dances. It can get crowded, so get there early if you can. Parking can suck, too, but it's worth it.
Love the live band performances! Oh! They have a coat check for $3 I think. Both male and females pay a $5 cover on Sundays. Good crowd, nice vibes and delicious food from the indoor restaurant too!

This review is for the food only. I didn't know it was a reggae bar and have never been for the music. Whenever I'm in town I always meet up with an old pal from school and she frequently suggests this place. Had it not been for her, I would have never known I could get some delicious Caribbean food on the Northside. Let's talk about their food!  I've had their jerk chicken and whoo wee it's good, but so are many things on the menu. I'm a fan of their Jamaican patties, coconut shrimp, and oxtail platter. My biggest complaint about the Wild Hare is that several things are frequently not available. That sucks if you really have your heart set on oxtail and rice or a patty. Three of the four times I've been, they've had at least one thing unavailable on the menu.   Meh, not cool. Since their food is good, I'll forgive them for this even though it is frustrating.

We celebrated a friends birthday here. The place looks small from the outside, but is actually larger than it appears. The food is fantastic, priced well and has large portions; my wife and I had to share a plate there was so much food. The rum punch does pack a punch, and its what we drank all night. Check out their happy hour, great deals.The service was perfect, nothing but great things to say about it. From the DJ to the live band, the music was amazing, we danced all night. We agreed we would return as soon as possible, we loved every aspect of this spot!! It does get crowded, but we don't care about that in a live music venue.

Exceeded all expectations! You've got to try their food. Surprisingly great food. Opens at 6, I recommend going then. We were one of two couples eating on a Thursday night. Red snapper delicious, also shared blackened chicken and egg roll appetizers.

Food and atmosphere are great. I went expecting to listen to good music and eat decent Caribbean food. My experience was that and much more. It was dead--Tuesday night so i didn't expect much--but the band was live and put on a great show.  The food, jerk wings dinner, was great. Service was pleasant and quick. I circled back in Friday night and, despite being crowded, they offered the same great service and food.  Will definitely be returning.

Came in with hubby to get our Darius and Nina on.  I bought a Groupon before our trip.  It was good for cover charge for 2 and 4 drinks.  With the Groupon you can only get Red Stripe or Rum Punch.  Not bad options but good to know.  We ordered the Jerk Wings for a snack and they were awesome.  Def a must try.  The bartender and bouncer were both really nice and went out of their way to chat with us.  I saw some reviews said they weren't friendly to tourists but that wasn't the case with us.  We came in on a Sunday night.  We were a little early, live music started at 10pm.  The band was good.  It was pretty dead though, if you are looking for a party vibe I would come on a Friday or Saturday.

I had an expiring Groupon that I forgotten about; thankfully I checked out this place! I remember the old Wild Hare in Wrigley but I was too young to party there, so I always stood outside to dance to reggae tunes.  The new Wild Hare is a great place; great food, great music, and great drinks. The jerk wings were seasoned well and not too spicy. I've been on a healthy kick so I got the sautéed vegetables that are stewed in a coconut milk and served over rice and peas. Mmmmmm it was so good and fresh. The live music was also a plus. I will definitely go back again.

Have been here on a tipsy night or two DRINKS: Drinks are average strength.  PERFORMANCES: They are lived, featuring authentic Caribbean bands, and are viewable from more than one place in the bar, due to TV screens placed in strategic areas.  ATMOSPHERE: Everyone wants to have avoid time, and people sometimes dance, but it seems to be mostly easy listening, in terms of activity

I checked out this place back in April and I loved it had a blast. Drinks were good and the food was amazing I had the jerk wings. Service wasn't bad just one bartender who came off rude. Overall place it great I'm actually going back this saturday for my birthday!
Love the Wild Hare!  Great music, drinks, but mostly the people are awesome!  Can't wait to go back!!

This place does not belong to be in Lincoln Park awful very rough crowd and while the price is awful people are doing drugs in here they have nowhere to park There was hair in my drink not very friendly or polite The speakers did not sound well It was very awkward I would rather go to Kingston mines This worst jerk chicken ever  a disgrace for Chicago

I came to Wild Hare for the first time on a Friday night. We got there close to 6:30pm (they open at 6pm) so it was pretty much empty inside except for a few older guys at the bar. The bartender was doubling as the waitress which was fine since there were so few patrons but did make it a little challenging when we needed to get her attention for something.  As for the food, I was pleasantly surprised. The waitress informed us that their jerk is on the sweet side as opposed to being spicy. I didn't find it to be sweet at all but I thought that everything had a good flavor. I ordered the jerk chicken dinner for $14 though you have to add $1 to switch to jerk wings. I found the rice and beans to be a little dry and flavorless but the plantains, cabbage, and chicken were all excellent. I also ordered the rum punch which was delicious but pretty pricy at $12. I'll be back to check out the reggae club scene at some point and will return for food as well.

Came here with a Groupon deal for drinks. We ended up getting dinner. The food was good! The jerk wings are worth going back for. They also have great drink specials everyday! We didn't stay for the show so  This review is just base on the food. If your looking for good food stop by!

Only place for reggae music in the city!! Their "award" wining wings are ok/inconsistent! Each time it tastes different, the most recent time the wings were heavily seasoned wasn't sure if I was eating chicken or herbs, the herbs overpowered the chicken. Seems to be better on the weekends vs weekdays. $10 for 6 wings isn't worth it unless you're REALLY starving. There's other place's in the area where the wings are better & you get more. There's even a place down the street that offer's .25 cent wing specials that taste better. Eat before you go!! Also pregame if you go, got charged $24 for 2 well rum drinks!!!!!! Would give it a 1 star if it wasn't for the music!

We came for dinner and some live reggae music. We ordered the coconut shrimp for appetizer. You could tell that it was totally hand prepared with fresh coconut and it was really good. My wife had the Jerk chicken diner with rice and peas, cabbage and sweet plantain. The rice waa a bit dry, the chicken was  yummy and so was the  cabbage. I had curried vegetables over rice N peas.  The veggies were perfectly cooked and the curry was with coconut milk. I liked it a lot. The whole meal was a very pleasant surprise. I was expecting just average, but no Mon! Thanks Wild Hare for knocking it out of the park.  Oh yeah there's live reggae here too. Come for the food and stay for the music.

My family hosted a private event here of roughly 100 people. Bill, Ted, everyone is simply outstanding! I honestly can't say enough about how kind,everyone is and how flexible and willing to work with us the team was, they are just all around good people. Most of our guests were from out of town and it was their first time to Chicago, to the area, and to jerk food. The food was delicious, the music and everything was perfect.  When my party left everyone was all smiles and happy they came. If you are considering the Wild Hare, stop considering and go for it. You will be more than happy you did. Thanks again.

Sunday night review. Very limited late night menu after 10pm. $12 mixed drinks, nice live band. Server was not attentive, took our order and checked on us 40 minutes later. From where we sat it was not very crowded. We walked out after we were told our order would be another 5 minutes even though the table next to us arrived/ordered after us and already received what appeared to be their entire order. I did receive my drink, the Jamaican Millionaire. Although it was a mixed drink it tasted much like tap water.

Tourist Not Welcome. Worst experience I have ever had, made Chicago look horrible. Came to The Wild Hare about 10:25pm with four people. We sat and ordered our food at 10:35pm at 11:30pm we had yet to receive our food. The waitress did not approach our table once as we waited to tell us that our food was taking long or ask if we were okay. Two couples that arrived 15min after us got their food before us. Very unpleasant service and make tourist feel very unwelcomed and poor service. Do not recommend.

Local, live reggae music, dudes in gold chains and white t-shirts, rum-drenched drinks, low lights and some booty shaking!! I mean....what's not to like. I was on full tourist mode and some friends wanted to find live music they could dance too. Thank you Yelp, cause, we found Wild Hare. We had had just enough liquid courage to be the first on the 99% empty dance floor (mandatory, slightly older dudes at the side tables staring, constituted the other 1%) but within an hour, the late night crowd arrived, and it was on a pop'n. Not perfectly polished, but, we got to hear two local artists give us their all. Braids swinging in the spot-light, people seemed happy as long as that hitch-rift from the band kept tempo. Non-pretentious, genuine and filled with winding hips, this is a great Friday late night spot to watch and listen.....or better yet....dance!

I LOVE this restaurant. I go eat here every chance I get. The chicken is excellent and so are the sides. I love the Jerk chicken dinner, that is the best deal although the oxtails are fantastic too. I like the live bands that play every night and the atmosphere. Definitely a place worth experiencing.

The food was good. I had the late night menu jerk chicken dinner. It was a large portion  (4 pieces of chicken). Stayed for the live music and DJ. DJ had me dancing the whole time. Great place to visit.
Used a Groupon. Went on a Sunday and there wasn't that many people. I may give it another chance but check it out on a Saturday.

It's misleading to advertise "Dancehall Wednesday's" and play very little of it... They played more hip hop and funk than reggae. It's unfortunate that there is a lack of clubs in the city but that doesn't give you the right to take the historic reggae club "Wild Hare" and make it a raunchy hip hop club. Truly disappointed! The bartender, Richard, gets 5 stars though!

Great venue to check out reggae music. About a 15 minute drive from Downtown area via Uber, this Caribbean bar charges a $5 admission fee. Apart from the music, my favorite part was that they served food late! Not to mention the food is tasty! We ordered the Jerk Chicken Wings and French Fries. The wings were soft and flavorful, but only enough to feed two. Surprisingly the fries were really REALLY good and a large enough serving to share with my party of 5! Took a while for our order to come out, but it appeared that lots of people were ordering. And I'm assuming there was only one cook considering it was 1AM. I did also appreciate the fact that they had a TV showing the current act, makes it easier for you to not miss anything if you are eating on the other side! Can't wait to return!

i liked the food and service, i mean everything.  the jerk chicken is actually smoked by the wood they shipped from Jamica!!!!!!!!  i will definately come back for the food, red stripe and the perfect live music they offer!

Absolutely love this place! The ambiance the food and the music gets an A+ from me.  The Jerk wings and the rum cheesecake is phenomenal! It gets a bit crowded on the weekends so be prepared to stand but if your a dancer and you love live reggae music you won't mind. Sunday nights are nice if you want to chill. sit and listen to music while enjoying a bite and drinks.

Great music venue. Staff is nice, cool bar. The jerk wings are pretty good.  Mixed drinks nothing to mention so go for the beer. A cold red stripe is all you need.  The regular bands they have are great.
Some of the best Jamaican food I have ever tasted!  Truth! Reggie Club with a live Band, 2 bars and restaurant. The clientele on the weekends can be a bit rough and rowdy, but who cares. Fun spot!
Nice lil spot. Good Food too. Rum punch is my fav.

The jerk chicken and all its sides (fried plantains, rice and peas, cabbage) were delicious.  Also, the service was attentive and friendly.  We just came in for food, so can't comment on anything else. Wish we had time to come back for music and dancing!

I'm so happy they moved to a bigger location! I hadn't been in years and wasn't looking forward to being in a over crowded space! A friend had a birthday gathering in the back room and we had an awesome time! Everything was on point from the live music to the great drinks!  I had two Jamaican Rums....just enough to get me right!  I love the fact that the Dj  switched up the music when the band took a break and we knew the songs from our high school days. Everyone was on the floor!  The jerk chicken and plantains were really flavorful and delicious although it took a long time for the food to arrive! Just glad it was still hot! It became crowded by the live stage area so renting the back was perfect!   The area is very congestion and parking on the street is nearly impossible however we were allowed to park in the Home Depot garage for $5.....the walk to the venue isn't bad although it Was one of the coldest night!  Great place for birthdays or after work with coworkers!
Saturday night was our first time  there. I absolutely loved the live Reggae music and the Atmosphere was great. Everybody was having a good time dancing. Would definitely go back

Absolutely LOVE this place! Awesome energy, real good musical vibes, and the drinks are right on! The food is really good, but I'd really like to see more options. It's a bar and dance club though, so I get it. It's the Jamaican take on bar food, with some tasty dishes. If they got a little more creative and extended their menu with more pastas, appetizers, or dishes ( with their spin on it) it would be a flawless experience. Seriously though, I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!
Great location for reggae, soca and calypso. Always a live band and lots of dancing. They also have Appleton and mount gay rum. Awesome. The vip lounge and bartender was also very professional.

I ordered jerk chicken and i was really looking forward to be blown away. However, I was not. They were burnt and chalky tasting. I did not finish them. I have had jerk chicken that is way better and I could also do a better job at cooking them. Nevertheless, the bartender was very nice so I did not complain. I may go back to give dinner another chance, 50/50.

These three stars are only for the music. The food is so inconsistent that you never know what you will get - the jerk wings that I had tonight should never be called jerk. It was smoked bland chicken at best. Much more to be desired.

Loved going here and the music/atmosphere. Definitely a place to check out occasionally. drinks aren't too expensive and fairly cheap tickets. In the back room, there's a huge dance floor and people actually dance here - really fun to go with a big group of friends.

Went to Wild Hare and was not happy with my experience. No parking, music very loud and nearly no one in the bar even on Friday night. The bartender wasn't attentive even with the limited people. The bass was so loud and overpowered the music completely, couldn't even distinguish the song. We couldn't hear ourselves think, let alone talk, so we had to leave for another bar.
Ok once again, I'm giving a review while I'm sitting at the bar... Amazing food cold and cheap drinks to match. The service is always on par. Don't pass this one up....

Went here a couple weeks ago for the besties bday and had a ball. Loved the atmosphere and the bands were great . Had the jerk chicken dinner which normally comes with dark meat but they substituted the dark for wings for me and it was pretty good ! The rum punch was off the chain our group got s nice buzz off of our first drinks . Will definitely be back !!!

Although the place was nice and deserted on a Tuesday, that's the norm and it's totally style. Nothing like having a bar to yourself with your babe, and a few food drink. My husband ordered jerk wings and said they were delicious! Band was playing great music and the vibes were super relaxing. Drinks were mellow not too weak and not too strong, and I love the feeling of the vibe. The employees get a long well. It's our first time in Chi-town and we're Only here for the night, glad to spend it amongst cool people on a drizzly Chicago night.

This famous Chicago landmark has always been on my list. When I lived in Chicago, I wasn't legal so now that I've got the credentials, I figured I would stop in with a friend from out of town. This was a completely random visit on a Saturday night. It was all street parking (free after 10pm!) with some parking by the Home Depot down the street. We walked in and there was cover (my buddy handled it but I assume it was $5-10/person) but free coat check. First you see a smallish bar with restrooms and can't possibly think you are in the right place. Follow the trail of swaying hips and you will snake around to a larger room and bar, with another room all the way in the back. The dance floor, with stage, is not very large but it was perfect for dancing. The crowd is African Americans, older (25-50 years of age) with definite island flavor mix in. There was a reggae band on stage and they were playing jams. We had a good amount of space to dance and it was just borderline packed. They don't seem to play a whole song. They constantly changed it up as if the drummer was steering the band.After about 20 minutes, the band disappeared with no timeline for their return so we decided to dance a bit then call it a night. It was still a good time. Drink prices are about what you would expect for the Northside. I got a honey Jack on the rocks for $8. They don't have some things that you would need for a premium cocktail (I couldn't get a Manhattan or a Sidecar) so think island and you will fit right in. My friend double fisted a Red Stripe and Jack on the rocks while we body rolled the night away. The Hare is jumping until 3am and around 1am the crowd was still manageable. I will definitely go back when I want to do some late night dancing like no one's watching.
The most recent time at the Wild Hare was last month. In Chicago visiting. We got there late, so we only heard about 15 minutes of a great band. I'll definitely be back though!
The place is ok overall.  The drinks are ok. The music is great due to the fact I love reggae.  Haven't tasted the food yet. Bartenders are not to attentive tho.

We came in early (7pm) on a Wednesday night for a drink before dinner at Cheng Du Impression across the street so the bar was empty but the bartender was sweet and the drinks were strong. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come back for the food but I am somewhat intrigued by the possibility of Jamaican cuisine closer than Uncle Joe's in HP.

I was expecting to be wowed away. You can look at the stars and see that I wasn't. The first problem was that there was almost no parking. I had to park on some side street down a back block. The second issue is that we had to pay for entry. Im like whoa, we were just going to eat. We walk in there isn't a lot of people here. Its pretty diverse with ages and ethnicity. So we took a seat at the bar the bartender was cool. Not to attentive but ok i guess. The inside looks like an old school bar with so tropical feel to it. I normally wont talk about an establishments bathroom. However the bathroom for guys at least breaks every man code imaginable. There are no toilets or urinals. There is only one long sink/tub with water running in it with a couple of drains in it. That poses a problem, no separation, no stalls yea i think not.  We ordered a side of fries and some of the jerk wings. The fries didn't taste fresh at all but I have had worse. The chicken was OK, I have had jerk wings and they are usually more charred or crispy. There weren't bad at all its just the texture and how soft they were threw me off quite a bit. The seasoning was good. There was a live band playing on the opposite side and we had no idea. I walked over to see another bar and a couple of tables. There were a few people scattered. I like reggae actually i love reggae. I like dub, ska, dancehall and roots. I would have like to have heard some upbeat reggae. We went on a Friday night around 10. There wasn't a lot going on. I was surprised by this. I think I need to go back on a different day for the music. I'm sure the food will be the same. So i will eat before hand.

Great atmosphere, people, and food!! We had the Jerk chicken dinner ( great jerk seasoning on the chicken and homemade hot sauce), plantains were good. We also had the jerk chicken wings. Wings were the bomb. Tender chicken meat and jerk homemade seasoning was great. I highly recommend you check out this divey Caribbean bar. Right down the street from the B.L.U.E.S and Kingston Mines. I'm glad we opted to try something new. Great find in the Lincoln park area.
This was a fun place.  Food is off the chain.  Only complaint is that it really got hot as hell.  The band for the night was great.  However, late in starting.

Dj was inconsistent, crowd was much older than expected. But me and the girls have fun where ever we go. But this was a one time experience, Ill go back to try the food. If you're early 20's subt on thursdays

Wanted to dance so I ended up at The Wild Hare on a Wednesday and I'm so glad that I did. There was no cover and the crowd was mostly in their mid to late 20s and early 30s. It was predominantly black, but as the night went on there was some diversity. After buying 2 long islands (the typical Chicago $12 each price), I got out there on the dance floor. There was no live band that night, just DJ's, which is exactly what I was hoping for. Several different DJ's took turns spinning the hottest reggae mixes that got the floor crowded and moving. Seriously, those were some good DJs.  As the floor got more and more packed and with a younger crowd, the DJ's got better but to be honest this place could do without the "island freakum team" bouncing their vaginas hard up and down on the floor. I mean don't get me wrong y'all. l love when other people dance and have fun; the more the better, which is why I had a blast turning up with dancer Sol (Sol runs a dance class there during the week) and some nice Haitian ladies. However, there was an awkward and desperate vibe when the girls employed to dance there came out and started rolling around on the floor, which not many seemed interested in. Overall it's a place worth going to and was really fun.

I'd give it 3, maybe 3.5 on a good night. Really like the music and feel of this place, plus it's within walking distance of my apartment, but it's a bit loud. Food is good, at least what I've tried and heard. The music is nice - good selection and live artists - but it can be a bit much. The bass is WAY too high so I feel like I'm shaking. Not my favorite place but certainly an experience.

Live music on a Friday night. 6 dollar charge. Good atmosphere. Three bars. Big place. I'll definitely be coming here again and try their Jamaican food since I just had drinks and had an amazing time.

I won't be back here based on the service.  The bartender was awful, the drinks were weak, and the food took forever....another couple ordered, ate, went to listen to music, came back out to ask how we liked our food and were shocked that we hadn't gotten our meal yet.   The only redeeming thing was the food itself.  It was delicious.  I guess this place is good for take-out.  As long as the food is ready when you go to pick it up.

Food was amazing! We ordered the wings(falls right off the bone but still crispy) and ordered the jerk chicken wrap. The wrap was no ordinary wrap definitely worth trying!  We will  be back to try the jerk chicken dinner platter to share.  We went on a Friday night around 8pm and had no problem getting a table. The only reason this place gets bad reviews is because the service isn't the fastest BUT that won't stop me from coming back and grubbing!!!
Live reggae on Wednesday nights, kitchen open late. Food was amazing. Ordered Jerk chicken, coconut shrimp, breaded cod and fries.

First time at the Wild Hare was amazing. Went to this place on sunday at 6pm because the ramen place next door was closed on sunday. We said why not and had no idea what kinda food it was. Walked in right when they opened to a wonderful hostess who was nice the entire time.  Never had Caribbean food before but knew that the go to item was the jerk chicken. Amazing right off the bat. It was presented beautifully and not just something that was slopped on. Came with a side of plantains that was cooked that melted in your mouth and you wish you had more. I am not a fan of spicy food at all. I had jerk chicken and the taste and spice was not what i thought it would be. It was a little bit spicy but not overwhelming that took away from the flavor of the chicken. The combo of rice and jerk chicken was perfect to compliment each other. Drinking a red stripe was the icing on the cake to make this meal complete.  I am currently on a diet but I know that this is on my hit list to go to again. Very glad to have stumbled upon this place.

Let me start off by saying that upon walking into the wild hare I was a bit underwhelmed. The entire feel of the place is dated and the lackluster sound coming from what they call a sound system is simply insulting. I ordered the "most popular" drink which i was told was the famous wild hare rum punch and to my dismay I received my drink with some black object floating in it. Now it's hard for me to discern what this piece of black nastiness was however I am quite sure that it shouldn't have been there. The server was very prompt in returning the drink and offered me another although I politely declined. The wild hare may be a fan favorite of the locals though for my first experience here one time is definitely enough.

I hate to do this to wild hare because I LOVE the club...the music is off the chain if you actually love reggae and dance hall.  So the club gets four stars (although maybe more ventilation or ac on the main floor would be good cause it is hot, sweaty and funky down there..I go directly to vip...uninvited.)  But I experienced something tonight that is illegal and got my attention. I ordered jerk wings from the station in the front of the club and the guy taking the order (Derrick he said his name was) took my money and slighted me almost a dollar in change.  When I noticed I stated you owe me change (probably 79 cents.) He said "We round up."  Meaning he wasn't giving the change.  I looked at him as if he were insane...we round up?  You don't get to round up...that is illegal.  your prices are as stated...the taxes are as stated..either round the taxes and price so you can give as little change as possible or provide change but you do not get to keep the customers money.  I notified him that this is illegal and that I was contacting the BBB (which I am.)  He offered me a comp meal etc...but I decided that it would be better to keep everyone from being fleeced by these scum bags then to get a free meal. Seems like a small thing right?  But it is not for a few reasons.  1. They are getting cash tax free from the customers that likely equals $100s of dollars per night.  It goes unreported and they don't "ask" you for it so it is essentially stealing.  2. It bothers me because the clientele is largely Black and or foreign so I guess they think we don't know any better (insulting.) 3.  I thought this was a minority owed business (I could be wrong) so why is the owner allowing this person to take advantage of his loyal customers.  We drink there, we dance there, we will eat there...but you must be respectful and not rob your customers...not even of 5 cents.  It is wrong and it adds up.  I wanted to leave this tonight.  I am contacting the BBB in the am.    Don't allow yourself to be scammed...not for a dime...money is tight and people should not be taken advantage of because they have been drinking...I guess I wasn't drunk enough.

Me and My Bestie wanted to unwind after a stressful work week. So I decide to use my Groupon for The Wild Hare. We get there around 8pm and there was no one at the door to check us. We waited and waited. Finally a guy comes back to the bar. I guess he was the waiter door check drink mixers all in one. I let him know that I have a Groupon. He tells me that there is no one at the door to check us inside. So basically don't buy the Groupon because it's free until later on in the night. SMH  Hot Damn. The reason for my 3 star review is because the food was good. It took a minute for the live band to come on stage. But once they got on stage after how many hours later. The place was jumping. Great mixed crowd and I'm we finally got a chances to unwind and get our drink and boogie on. Just don't waste your money on a Groupon. Get there early for a free admission and a good table.

I used to go to the old location ALL THE TIME.  Especially back in the 80s & 90s.  I'm disappointed in the new location.  Not only in the size but that there was initially no live music.  LIVE MUSIC WAS THE REASON GO TO THE WILD HARE.   I've heard and seen the advertisements that there is live music now but their website has no notice of who is playing or what the hours of the band performances NOR do they advertise this info in the Reader.  The Wild Hare will never be the same.
I love this reggae club! I have so many great memories here! Various reggae bands regularly perform here as well as djs that spin reggae mixes! Always a fabulous time!

Walked in yesterday for a quick bite.  Started with a Red Stripe ($5) not bad at all. For an appetizer we had the jerk chicken wings and they are super delicious!!!! My bf 's new favorite!   I could probably eat 2 or 3 orders of wings by myself and I'd be happy!! We also ordered the wrap with veggies instead of the jerk chicken and a house side salad.  After finishing the jerk chicken wings we thought we made a mistake but the veggie wrap did not disappoint!!!! Still very delicious!  The house side salad said it came with mango vinaigrette but it didn't taste like mango.  I guess that was a good thing because it was still very good! Service was good and the atmosphere had us wishing we were on vacation!  We'll be back for sure!

I really really wanted to fall madly in love with this place... But it just didn't happen.  We came on a Friday night and the crowd was decent. 1. This place says it is wheelchair accessible which is important for me because I am in  wheel chair. But the entrance was so small and narrow that I could barely get through. Not to mention that as soon as you finally get through the door the bar area is immediately right there.  Once in no one really greeted us or gave us direction on where to sit so we wandered around a bit. We finally found some where to sit. 2. No one asked if we wanted to order food. My friend went and found menus and we placed a food order.  We than went to the bar, the waitress was very nice and the drinks were on point. The food never came. My friend went to the counter three different times and an hour after ordering we finally got our food.  And guess what...you got it it was cold. However the plaintain were excellent, but the chicken was a little burnt and didn't have the spicy kick that I expected. We had some mango pie they reccommended and it was not pleasant. Oh yeah...the busboy told us to pay now cause he wasn't coming back over there.. 3. I know...its a reggae club but they need to switch the music up some. At some point you get tired of it. 4. Bathrooms...I mentioned the wheelchair thing. Yeah...thankfully I have some mobility or I would have been a wet mess. My friend and I referred to it as the green mile. One straight, narrow entrance and small 'accessible' stalls. I don't know... I wanted to like it but it just didn't live up to the hype. If you're looking for a good time... At a reggae spot I suggest Mr. Browns lounge.
love this spot. been tons of time for music but recently tried the food and it was awesome.

Most people seem to only know this place for live reggae music and a late night party spot.  Little do they know that this place also has some amazing Caribbean and Jamaican food (which is hard to find in Chicago.)  Both times I came here was actually around 7-8pm just for dinner and a couple drinks before hitting up Kingston Mines and BLUES.  Since most people dont know about the food, the place is pretty empty at that time but dont let that scare you off.  Everything we ordered was excellent.  The jerk chicken wings, the turkey burger, and the jerk chicken platter were all fresh, spicy, and flavorful and served with plantains rice and a delicous spicy, sweet Calypso sauce which they make in house.  They also had a house tropical cocktail which was really good.  Prices are reasonable also.

Will never come here again.  After waiting 2 hours to hear the band, still no band.  Kept being told 5 minutes.  Was so looking forward to hearing reggae.  Wanted a refund on principal that I never heard a band and paid cover for one.  What a rip off!

This legendary club is  Chicago's prime spot for quality live reggae. The vibe is so nice, and it is run by folks that know reggae inside and out. The food is tasty, and the music is crucial. They had a great run in wrigleyville from 1981-2012, and brought over tons of great reggae artists from Jamaica, as well as being a home base for the local reggae heroes, and became one of the best reggae clubs in America! They moved to their current location and are continuing their run of excellence. This is THE place to hear live reggae music in Chicago.

The Wild Hare used to be the best place to go in wrigleyville. I decided to go on Saturday Jan. 17 when Carl Brown did his show his music has changed, the crowd was different I was disappointed but I'll give it another chance.
So glad to see they've reopened!!!!  Yaaay Wild Hare!
Absolutely adore this place. Great live music and jams to boogie to. Melissa is a dream and knows how to make consistent cocktails. Thank you

Been there at least a dozen times this year, mostly since they finally got their live performance liscense a few months ago. The food is unbelievably good. The bartenders are among the fastest and nicest in Chicago. The artists who perform there are amazing. Only two big negatives: The dj's can't mix well ,and they love the sound of their own voices.  ALWAYS talking over the songs, and this is annoying as hell.  Bad enough to listen to bad mixing breaking up the vibe, but talking/screaming is for the clubs that the youngins go to, not for the reggae club.  The only thing worse than a dj who can't mix is a dj who can't mix and talks all over the beat like Clue.  Fortunately, they only play when the bands are done.  Let's put it like this.  Almost all the dj's get one star, especially the main one, and the club gets 4 1/2 otherwise. Also there is an emmcee who interrupts the performers at every show with this lame call and response routine.  Audiences come to see a performane, not to perform.  NOBODY wants to PAY to see a show and have it predictably interrupted EVERY TIME with the whole Do you want one more song?  Do you want two more songs?   You're not loud enough.  Everybody say "Irie!"   -  Dear God, just shut up and get off the stage so we can hear the band, and stop telling the crowd they're not loud enough!  Normal people don't go to a reggae club to scream! Drinks are a tad on the pricey side, but worth it.  Sometimes a little too crowded to move, because the new space is so small. If you're looking for a good live reggae performance though, this is the best place in Chicago for it.

One of my favorite places, awesome vibe, great music and incredible food. Know the main attraction is the music, but absolutely come here for the food any night. The ox tail w/polenta and the jerk chicken are really, really good.
I love the wild hare. I'm so happy that they got there licensee, but I wanna address few changes, both the male bar tender need to fix there attitude,
Ordered the Jamaican jerk chicken dinner.  Good stuff.  Friendly cook and bartender.  Great music.
Live reggae music is back at The Wild Hare.  The dance floor was packed with smiling dancers of all races and ages enjoying the great reggae vibes.

Came here late on a Saturday night (or maybe more like within the early hours of Sunday Morning) and the place was packed. I can't say anything about the food and drink because I didn't have any, but the atmosphere was very laid back and chill. For a completely unpretentious night out dancing to reggae, this is a decent place.  There was a DJ, the music was loud, it was pretty dark, and because there were so many people there was very little space to dance but we made do.  The bouncer was very nice, helped me up as I fell over my feet walking out the door (I swear I didn't have anything to drink there, I am just clumsy).  Definitely reeked of weed outside, I guess adds a little more authenticity to the Jamaican feel of the place.

They almost got 5 stars but they overbooked their private room on my 30th birthday and there was no food order as requested. I sent my deposit and everything back in March, talked to Bill up until 7/08 - I was totally upset! However, they did supply a small section in the bar area of the business, sent over champagne and refund my money back! I couldn't ask for a better way to rectify the mishap - it was good to know business owners care about their patrons. Tip: If you are having a provate party call the place and speak with that person, do not go through the email address because the owners don't communicate......as I experienced first hand. Location is easy to get to, there is a 5.00 parking garage across the street which I thought was awesome. The drinks were strong and although no live band (yet) the DJ was awesome. My friends and I had a ball - take the lemons and make some lemonade.....it was great!
Saturday night is the best night. They have conch fritters which gets me to go. That and the bartender Richard is cool peeps.

My cousin and I just had our birthday party here on Saturday and I can't express how much fun we had! From beginning to end Asrat and Amiir were absolutely wonderful with the planning and preparation process. On the day of, everything was set up on time. The bartender was a lot of fun and the food was delicious. The music was A++. There were even times when people were trying to crash our party and the security guard definitely regulated. Overall, I would recommend The WildHare for parties or just to hang out with friends. Great Times!

Worth the wait for awesome food!  I had the burger (one of the best I've had) and my wife had the coconut tilapia which was awesome!  Also their specialty drink is run punch for only $5.  We'll be back when we're in the area.
It was a very disappointing evening. I want to say we came out on the wrong night. There was no dj, a reggae track was playing. Very different from the old wild hare which I miss terribly :-(

This is a great place. The Decor is very chill. Came here on NYE with my wife the place is really comfortable. The food is great. The service was top notch. Hopefully they can get there live music license. Just read an article that is was denied twice for due to the racist people of the neighborhood saying this place attracts gang bangers really? Wild Hare is known for bring people of all races together.  Will definitely be back.

Decided to check this place out on a cold Friday night out. It was pretty easy to find and had a welcoming atmosphere. The menu listed online of the beers is what brought us to the establishment, which was also was one of the downsides- they were out of all the Caribbean beers (Carib, Presidente, Red Stripe, Jamaican Stout, St. George, etc!) It was disappointing, but the bartender was really nice and they did have some Ginger Beer :) The inside was deceiving at first. We thought that it was just a bar with a small stage and a little window to the kitchen, but after I headed to the Ladies' Room, I saw there was a whole other half! More dancing space, tables, bigger stage, and bigger speakers with louder music. Much better on that side for dancing, or sitting in a booth to people-watch dancers as you sip your drink. I enjoyed my time there. Music was a great mix of old and new reggae, and some soca too. It is great to find a place here that feels authentic with Caribbean vibes:)  Will definitely come back soon!

I'm not one of those people who write reviews on everything as this is my first review but I had to construct one on this joint. I've been going here with my folks for the past few weekends & I am now addicted! Have yet to have dinner at the place but have been breaking a sweat with my husband jukin to the reggae tunes. I knock back a few drinks & lose myself in the music. When I do go, my man & I are the couple that get the party started, the ones that make you go "I can't believe they did all that!". That's how good the music & the atmosphere make you feel.  The bartender is cool, tip him & he'll give you a couple of free drinks. They have this long seating bench that makes giving lap dances easy, (no it's not a strip joint, at least when you're sober lol). Have seen the private room, looks nice but never partied in it. The bathroom does suck, it has very small stalls in the women's but it's not like much time is spent there anyways. Still had to give the place 5 stars because I make the fun when I get there. No one's arguing, no one's fighting, it's not the kind of rowdy club that you have to bring a shank or worry about getting shanked. It's pure fun, or at least what we make of it. Try it out, I'll be there!

I love this place!! This bar is a Chicago icon in the genre of Reggae music. It has re-opned, moving from its original location in Wrigleyville. Now it has found a wonderful home in Lincoln Park, not to far from Kingston Mines. They also serve food now and the menu raises the bar for bar food. I learned they just received their live music licence so pretty soon all the top notch reggae acts will be trickling through this historic venue once again. Do yourself a favor and check it out if you haven't already. You will be glad you did.
SIMPLY AMAZING - best jerk chicken i've ever had, friendly staff and so worth it!.  The portions are amazing as is the full offering that comes with the meal.  Cant wait to go back!
Ran out of drink basics at 10pm on a Friday night!! No more live bands w/ the new venue....not good!! This IS the US & not Jamaica! At least the tunes in one of the rooms is off the hook!

Best reggae club in Chicago. Large dance floor, so you can actually move to the music you came for. Fun diverse crowd that is into reggae, unlike most of the fratty DB scene in Wrigley. Live bands are a great time!

The staff here is absolutely AMAZING!!!! The new menu is delicious and everything is under 11$!!!! Big size plates, the fish was fresh, the server/ bartender was extremely nice. I heard their music license has been an issue, and since I live in the neighborhood I'm quite shocked as to why people would want to protest the license! Anyways I'm rooting for you guys! Loved the rum punch! Yea mon!

I came here with a groupon. The place was totally empty, and given that, the service was a little slow. They didnt have live music that night but the waitress was really helpful- she mentioned that all the food gets cooked from scratch, and thats why the wait is longer for some dishes. We tried the guac with chips and those chips were plantains. They were kind of awesome. Post that I had the rasta pasta, and dinner buddy had the jerk tilapia. The portions are super large, enough for 2 to share, even if you have a good appetite. I wouldnt say the food was amazing, but it was well cooked and had a home made feel to it.  The place itself looks like a big bar, with some seating on the side for diners. The bathrooms are a little oddly placed, but what bothered me more was the lack of toilet paper in some of them. And also, that there were no hand towels to wipe your hands when you are done washing them.  A fun place to go for a low key night.

What a great time!  This place looks deceivingly small from the outside but go in -- it's huge!  Fortunately, the staff gives a great deal of attention to its guests.  Truthfully, our waiter (with the beautiful dreds) made the experience a lot of fun.  We started with the "house special rum cocktail."  I'm still not completely sure what was in it but we went through at least two each. It's a shame I can't add photos to my review because they say it all.  EVERYTHING we ordered (and they were 5 of us) was beautifully presented from the appetizers to the deserts.  I strongly recommend the jerk chicken -- large portions and perfectly seasoned.  It came with a pyramid of seasoned rice and a green vegetable (not sure what it was but it was every bit as good as the chicken).  Another favorite was the coconut encrusted tilapie.  To finish off the perfect meal, we ordered the plantain/mango split and the sweet potato bread pudding -- both were delictable! If I could give this place more than 5 stars I would.  Take a chance, you won't regret it.  Can't wait to go back.
I absolutely love this place! It is enormous and both times I've gone the bands have been great. Great mixed crowd and awesome vibes.

Love love love!! beautiful layout, great atmosphere. This place is huge, you'd be fooled by being outside and looking in the window. Went here on a date a couple weeks back. Never knew they reopened-relocated until I walked past. Great food, and drinks (although needing more selections, esp. on the beer). It got even better when they opened the other side of the place up! Huge dance floor, couches, and bar. They have a stage and a third room!! I would definitely be back to groove to some good music and drinks w/ friends!
The food was great and the server was extra friendly and accommodating. Also the Wild Hare Pale Ale was a really refreshing beer. Give it a try if you're there!
Nice change up from the typical Lincoln Park/Depaul venues. Music is fantastic and the staff is amazing. Hoping there will be live music soon. Looking forward to headed back soon to try dinner!
After a two hour wait, we have half our entrees.  For a group of 6, unreasonable.  Appreciate the free drinks but the restaurant is empty, c'mon guys, pick up your sticks.

This place is simply awful. A group of 4 of us ordered 2 appetizers and 4 entrees and it took over an hour and a half... and it wasn't even crowded! Moreover, the time between the first entree being delivered and the last was probably 10 minutes... that's just awkward (And the first entree was cold when it was delivered... if you're not going to deliver the entrees together, then at least deliver them when they are warm).  Also, they were out of half of the things (Menu items, beers, etc.) that we asked for. I'm not even mad, I'm just disappointed - never before has a place that has gotten just such good Yelp reviews been so bad.  To be honest, the food was actually tasty (Albeit ranging from cold to lukewarm in temperature), but I simply can't condone a bar taking over an hour and a half  to deliver food. And it wasn't just the food - when they delivered the appetizer, they didn't bring plates. And evidently we forgot to ask for silverware when we asked for the plates because we had to eat the appetizers without silverware. They also forgot drink orders multiple times and rarely checked on us. If you want a taste of Jamaica, this is your spot - the food is tasty, and the service is as slow and poor as you can imagine... it's Island Time mon!

One of the best Jamaican inspired places I have ate in, since moving to Chicago. The venue itself is  a good size with three rooms all together. One room houses the bar as well as some high tables for dining, second room has a stage as well as dining seating and third room is closed for now until business picks up (which I'm sure is soon). Once they get their music license they will have late night reggae performance, now back to the food .  The menu selection is not the biggest, but of great quality (oh so I think!!!!). If you're going with a huge group or want to get your money's worth definitely get the spinach deep appetizer its delish and pretty big. If you want something heavenly go with the coconut shrimp. When it comes to main dishes I recommend the jerk salmon. It was cooked to perfection and the flavor was amazing. My boyfriend had the tilapia and that was pretty delishes as well, but in my opinion the salmon takes first place hands down. They also have some more traditional Jamaican cuisine such as the jerk chicken.  All in All when you're in the mood to Jerk, the Wild Hare is the spot for you.

I remember this was the hot raggae spot in Lakeview/Wrigleyville which was featured in the movie Love Jones in 1997. I heard they closed a few months ago and I was like  wow, but I have to admit this place seemed out of place in drunk ass, immature and classless Wrigleyville. My girl saw that they had a Groupon a couple of weeks ago and noticed the place was a 5 minute walk from us. We went over on a Saturday night and the place was pretty empty on a mild Saturday evening...I dont think a lot of peeps know that its there yet, but its finally in the right spot, a stones throw north of B.L.U.E.S. & Kingston Mines. Our waiteress was superb as she gave us all the info we needed in reference to the menu. We started out with the fresh & creamy spinach callalo dip. We expected a nice small portion of dip, but was friggin huge...we could have ordered it as an entree as it was so big. It came with tortilla chips and scotch bonnet salsa...it was delicious. For my entree I decided on the sauteed jerk tilapia with rice & peas....phenominal!!! My girl got the wood smoked jerk salmon and it was definitely the best I have tasted in quite some time. The place itself is cool as they have TVs on the wall playing raggae concerts and videos. They also play raggae music while you dine to set the rasta mood..lol Its nice that i can walk to this joint and I cant wait to see a live show here

This place rules. Not only is the food original and so tasty, but the service is friendly and the vibe is relaxed and easy. I got (and thoroughly enjoyed!) the jerk burger. They have an interesting Caribbean take on American food - and I've heard great things about the coconut shrimp. Reasonably priced, and completely delicious. They've kept a lot of the same crew of employees around from the recently closed Wild Hare - love that loyalty. They're still waiting on a live music permit because of neighborhood restrictions... but once it's all up and running, this place will be a Chicago gem.  I will definitely be back!

This a great place for jerk chicken! It recently re-opened (I think they were in a different neighborhood before) and so they are still working on some things. However, the food is great. I would recommend the pizza and any of the chicken!  Prices are reasonable too. I know at some point they plan to have concerts but they are still working on getting the license for it. A nice, casual and laid back place to hang out. Check it out!

Love the food -- was there last Tuesday with my girlfriends.  I had their jerk chicken, a friend of mine had the jerk burger and my other friend had ordered Talapia --- each dish was so delicious! We drank, ate and then finished our night out their key lime cheesecake -- can't wait to go again!  Also looking forward to hearing live music once more!
After a long wait The Wild Hare is back! Fans, old friends, neighbors, everyone needs to check out this Chicago staples new home! Don't miss the delicious food on their new Caribbean menu -- amazing!
GREAT NEWS! The Wild Hare is re-opening at a new location in Chicago on N. Halsted. I'm as giddy as a school girl!! Hopefully it will have the same spirit as it did before!
Sad to hear Wild Hare is gone. Miss you Miss you
Has this happened? chicago.cbslocal.com/201…

Loved being there hearing great live music in college and into the mid 90's.  It is leaving and taking a piece of my reggae band loving heart along. Good luck, peace and blessings to the owner for having a place where a reggae lover could lisen dance and have joy.

I love the Wild Hare! I haven't been in a while, but it used to be my second home. I really miss going there. Most nights, they have excellent reggae bands. If you are into reggae, I definitely suggest checking it out:)

It's Friday night and as we're walking down the street, this funky, reggae music is blasting and we check it out. As soon as you walk in, it reeks of weed in here. Total pothead, stoner place, but good times. Think Bob Marley. I'm not a stoner and need to feel some buzz going on so I immediately go to the bar. This pretty bartender asks what we want. I tell her "something fruity & yummy." She makes us some drinks 2 for $15. Good deal. They're absolutely delishhh! They taste like fruit punch. I had 2 of those & had a little buzz going, but not drunk at all yet. After some dancing and drinking we head on out. This is a cool chill spot. If you're a stoner, get stoned then come here. You'll totally enjoy it. The only thing is that there's not many seating options available. There's an upstairs but you need to do a coat check for that. My group stayed on the main floor. The bathrooms are downstairs and they're not tiny like every other bar. Live bands is what makes it unique and awesome. Very authentic, Jamaican feel. You'll be sure to encounter a bunch of guys with dreadlocks and a Jamaican accent. Everyone's super nice. Rachel Marie is an awesome bartender, ask for her!!

Maybe I hit the Wild Hare on an off night- but it was Saturday around midnight and there was no band?  In the absence of music to unite the crowd, it was painfully evident that we were in the wrong place. As a group of 6 girls, we were the only people I could see that were under the age of 50. Each of us were propositioned at one point by men old enough to be our dads. Sorry, fellas- no daddy issues here.  Drinks were expensive- which was expected in this part of town- but they weren't particularly strong or good. We stayed for one drink and then got the hello dolly out of there.

Lord a mercy, I just had the best time in Wrigleyville and I can't believe it!  I came here with a bunch of friends on Saturday (unfortunately the same day as the dreaded DMB concert in Wrigley Field) to celebrate one of my friends 30th birthday. Outside, there were obscene amounts of douche-nozzle activities going on, but inside The Wild Hare we were shaking our money makers to an awesome live band called Rico, who put a really fun and unique afro-cuban twist to traditional Santana, Bob Marley, and James Brown songs as well as, their own original songs, that I thoroughly enjoyed.   I would certainly go back to see more live music here.  It's one of the most unique live music venues I've been to in a while, it's just the location that sucks.

Man, I hate this place and I'm not sure why. Maybe it's because I'm not a reggae fan. Maybe it's because the two times I've been here it's been overloaded with baggy-pants wannabe gang banger kids from the suburbs. Maybe it's because it's a Wrigleyville bar. Maybe I'm just too musically lame to ever know of any band playing here.  I dunno. This is a solid "Eek! Methinks not."

I always have a good time when I'm at The Wile Hare.  However, I hate the outrageous cover they try and charge people... kinda stupid, especially because I've never once actually paid what they ask. However, this has the best live reggae music in Chicago and is full of super friendly people who just want to have a good time and enjoy the music. I like their drink concoctions that get you super drunk and taste delicious.. always a fan of that and red stripe! Escape from all the crappy, douchey bars in the Wrigleyville area, and come here after a game instead.  You'll have a great time!

If you like reggae, this place has AWESOME live reggae and although it has a cover, it is well worth it.  Get a red stripe, don't get a red stripe, THEY DON'T CARE! I personally have been to Jamaica and loved it.  Being at the Wild Hare brought me back, and made me wish I could go back right now! It's the shizz, BOY-YEEEE!

I was surprised when I found out where this venue is located. Exodus as well...just a stone's throw (or a drunk's stumble) from Wrigley Field, I feel its location has tarnished its authenticity. The crowd is only "diverse" after 11:30pm. I didn't pay a cover, even on a Friday night, because my friend knows the bouncer. But, I think I would've been satisfied. The reggae was a bit commercial, but I'm white enough to not notice so much. Later on in the evening I think it got better (or I got drunker, or both!) People here complained about the price of the drinks, but if you're getting a mixed drink they do not cheat you on alcohol. I like that it's not overcrowded- you can go dance on the dancefloor and when you're tired there's a seat either at a table or along the wall and there's room to move around. The bathrooms were very clean and there were a lot of stalls. I hate waiting in long ladies room lines! All in all, I think it was a fun place to go and I'll definately be back.

Went here for an event.  Left my credit card accidentally and didn't realize it for a few days, that is, until I checked my bank account and noticed they'd charged me $45 for three drinks that were $4 each.

So we escaped out of Wrigley Field as fast as possible after the Sox lost 1 - 0 to the Cubs.  While I'm not a big fan of Wrigley bars after Cubs games we decided to stop off and have a few.  We ducked into The Wild Hare because it didn't look crowded and the employees enticed us in from the street.  I must say I was very pleasantly surprised! The one thing we noticed was that we seemed to be among friends right along with a good crowd of other Sox fans.  I don't know if this place appealed to us because we were trying to avoid the typical Wrigleyville bar or what but hey, I wasn't complaining.   There was a great reggae band playing and it was nice to hear live music on a Sunday night.  The bar is spacious and clean and the staff was attentive.  The crowd was mixed and the vibe was very upbeat.  There's something about listening to reggae bands that just put me in an island state of mind!! So my White Sox lost but at least we were able to find a new fun Wrigleyville bar!!  You should check it out no matter what team you root for!  :)

This place is a hidden gem in Wrigleyville. Among all of the frat party, sports bar type establishments in the area, sits the Wild Hare, a place that boasts the most diverse clientele in the area, as well as some great music. Every time I've come here they've had some great Reggae bands as well as an awesome in-house DJ. I love the island decor and the lighting, it creates a great ambiance. My only complaint about this place is the fact that I paid $7.50 for a well drink. Seems a little much, but other than that, this place gets an A in my book. You must stop here if you're ever in the Wrigleyville/Lakeview area.

LAWD How I LOVE this place !!! .. . It's for the Young and Old at Heart!! I say this because each time that I go, I always get a glimpse of the over 50 women with short jeans skirts looking for their Rasta Man! ha ha ... The music is Fantastic!! after getting a 2 week earache, I've learned to listen to the bands upstairs or towards the back.. I hate that there isn't much seating but if you wear comfy shoes and you're going to dance, who needs chairs ? I guess I could pretend that I was in my 20's or early 30's.. Yea.. That age. The drinks could be improved but you aren't going to look cute! you're going to get your Groove on with the Fabulous Bands that come from all over the US!! .. LOVE IT!

Why not 5 stars? I've had amazingly stronger drinks. These were aiiight, but who would go for the drinks anyway? it's about the music. For being on the North side, I was surprised (in a good way) to see some diversity. And I mean everyone was represented the night I went. I went for a live show, but the music they played beforehand (reggae) was great. And they have dancehall on Wednesdays (plus!). Pretty good atmosphere, nice open space to dance with a little area to chat. I had good experiences with the staff.  Thumbs up.

Went last night.. was R&B ole' skool night, which I ADORE!!  I always have a good time at this spot, the drinks are nice and the bartender (she) was hellza cool.  Tip her well and she will make you some bomb concoctions.  I especially like the club because they play reggae music, the space, drink specials, and the sound system.   The live reggae bands usually tear down the house honey!  And the cover won't make you cry.  The crowd was friendly and fun-loving.  Parking is of course difficult cuz its near Wrigley field, but who cares.  Let's face it there will always be some creepy guy that stares at you... hell sometimes I get that look in the grocery store.  Foooh-get about it... life is short get your groove on and make some new friends. The owner is very gracious.  But, don't mess around.. security will have you hemmed up (yeah I said hemmed).  Where's the coat check, please?... I'm staying.

I really enjoyed this place. Great music and great people having a good time. The guy at the door was great and hella friendly. Even though I wasn't in the mood to be out, the people around me inspired me to go again.  The crowd was very diverse culturally and age-wise as well which is always great.  If you have a problem with diversity or Reggae music...you probably shouldn't go because thats whats was great about it for me!  one more thing about the sketchy men: is there any bar-club type setting where tipsy/drunk men aren't a little sketchy after 10pm? certainly not. And at the Wild Hare everyone just wanted to have a good time (no ones trying to attack you violently), stop being paranoid and self absorbed only because someone looks at you...or take it as a compliment and keep it moving.
I do like this place! The live reggae is always on point. I have to side-eye the cover charge a little bit, but I'd still go back.

I just want to snap on all the stuck up snobs who don't know a great joint if they picked it out themselves.  The wildhare is ubber hot. It's fun, it's casual and you can wear whatever you friggin want to. Wear heels, that's cool, but if you really want to dance and never sit down, I wouldn't recommend those. I wore flats the first time I went, the second time, i wore heels and went to the car after 30mins to change into my flats.  So, the music was hot. There weren't too many sketchy guys, but then again, I was with the boo so no one, really, bothered me. Ultimately, this place is hot, and I will be back, EVERY SUNDAY IF I CAN.  Meet me there.

Man you guys, I read all the reviews (ok, some) for the Hare and was prepared for a scary, expensive, too-aggressive man experience - none of which delivered. The Wild Hare was a great place to see my beloved Toots & the Maytals, the Red Stripe is only five bucks, the loo was clean and there were a few of them, the staff was all very friendly and the sound was great.  No creeps, plenty of room to shake my tail feather, a liberal in-out policy and space to boogie. Sold. I'm going back to Wild Hare on a non-concert night to take in some tunes of the islands. Very solid.

If you love reggae then this a good place to come too. The music from the DJ and the live bands are great. They have 2 bars, one upstairs and one downstairs. The bathroom is clean and the drinks are fine. Go about 10 at night. That's when it's jumpin! I paid $20 for parking cuz I parked in a lot across the street. So if you go in a group, then you can just divide that.

I went here on Thanksgiving, just because it was one of the only bars open around and the guy I was with knew the owner so there was no cover. Small little dump. Not impressed. Drinks were pricey and not well made. Music was irritating but what can you expect its reggae. It really only seems like desperate people who had nothing better to do on thanksgiving went there or that was the normal crowd. yuck. but what can i say...i was there, wasn't i?
Good place for late night fun and dancing! expensive drinks though.

I am giving this three stars mostly b/c my review is based on personal preference.  I am not a huge fan of the whole reggae scene but I was hoping to be inspired by going here.  I was not.  We had to pay $10 to get in and listen to a band that seemed to play the same song over and over again.  A previous reviewer described the guys as "stalkerish" and I have to agree.  One guy kept jumping between me and a few other friends and it was kind of creepy. None of us even feigned interest.  Anyways, drinks were ok, price to get in was ridiculous and the music was just ok.  If you're into reggae, check it out. If not, stay away b/c there is not much to offer you there.

I have a blast here. This is easily a must go to spot in Chicago for live reggae music. The drinks are CRAZY high, so I suggest bringing those little airplane sized bottles in your pocket or your girls purse... Cut's the cost way, way down. But the bands are great, and plenty of room for dancing. Overall, it's an enjoyable experience.

Went here a few weekends ago after Uberstein got too crowded & my friends got too drunk. While one friend was pulling on one arm to go to another wrigleyville bar, the other was pulling on my other arm pulling me towards Wild Hare Ltd. Much to my surprise everyone agreed upon Wild Hare. I was a bit turned off by the cover charge (you know being a girl & all, I kind of forget that people, mainly men, have to do this quite frequently), but when a kind soul offered to pay I thought-what the hell & went in. Little did we know what we were in for... First of all, I walked in with 4 friends & quickly realized we stuck out like sore thumbs. We were a)the only white kids there, b) had no idea what band was playing, and c) had no idea how to dance to Reggae. This wasn't anything a few Miller Light's couldn't fix. By the end of the night I was directly in front of the stage dancing like no one was watching. I didn't care how much of an idiot I looked like-I was having a good time! The music was great & seemed to go on forever. It was something I'll never forget. I doubt I'll be back though just because it wasn't somewhere I felt comfortable or welcomed whatsoever. Also, when my friend Beth asked for a cup of water the bartender said no. Umm, hello-that's awful. I then proceeded with "can she get a cup of ice then?" & the bartender was just not having it. Ah well, good for a random adventure in my lovely Windy City!

Fun reggae bar. I've only been here twice, but had a good time each time. $15 is a little steep for a cover, even on a weekend, especially for a place that doesn't even have Stella (what?!), but beat the 11:00 PM cut-off and you're in free. It's fun, there's lots of dancing, and if there's a Cubs game on, it's playing on a huge screen behind the music stage. Pretty nifty.

I'm a huge reggae fan and I've never had a bad time at Wild Hare.   The crowd is usually pretty mellow from what I've seen*. Although I normally go to Wild Hare for the music, not to meet new people.  I think that seems to be the popular mindset there.     *All of this goes out the window if its a post-cubs game crowd. The drinks can be a bit expensive but I normally stick to the Red Stripe.  Avoid asking the bar tender for a shot of "something jamaican" as one of my alcohol intolerant friends had.   You will likely end up with something called "Overproof" which tastes a lot like rubbing alcohol and shoe polish.    The $12 cover is a bit much but its worth it for the live music.

Great place to bring an out of town group of friends who want something other than the typical live music scene of Wrigleyville. Not to bash other bars live music. I am an avid attender of many genres and establishments but this one even surprised me.  A little more on the pricey side though...

This was the 1st stop after the Cubs game on my friend's birthday and while it wouldn't be a place I would suggest....I ended up having a really fun time.  The bartenders were great, the band was awesome, and the environment just made it an all-around good time.  Maybe I was just really drunk.

Really swell reggae. The bouncers could not possibly be more chill.  It's just too bad that the drinks are astronomically expensive and the clientele suck. Many of the folks there were lost Cubs fans, dancing in that embarrassing "this is how white dudes get down" sorta way. It  hurt to watch. Other dudes were trolling for late night love, and were pretty persistent in strategically dancing nearer and nearer to their chosen targets, and striking up conversations when you clearly wanted to just groove, or asking you to please leave with them. Naw thanks, daddy-O, I'm here for the music. There were four very entertaining, probably pretty regular fellas who were jiving right next to the stage and were all about loving everybody. One of them roped me in and we jumped around before he hopped on stage to help the singer out. I don't remember who was singing that night, but he was passioinate about w33d (read: sang about the delights of ganja for a solid 15 minutes) and took a half hour break to go mackin' and get some phone numbers. Hilarious. The drinks were out of this world expensive ($7.50 for a vodka tonic. Yowch!) so I would suggest, for maximum enjoyment of the Wild Hare, that you get rip roaringly drunk beforehand, and then all of those  awkward unlikeable things about it will just disappear and it will be just you, reggae and wonderful people. Get drunk. It helps a lot.

4 stars for the live reggae 2 stars for the $12 cover Like many have said there aren't a lot of places in the city you can regularly find live reggae, let alone good, live reggae. Again, I was disappointed by the $12 cover (we went on a Friday so I'm not sure if it's usually that much), but the guy cut us a deal and let us in for 1/2 off. We got there around midnight and the place was only mildly crowded - maybe a lower cover would produce more of a crowd.  When we got there the band was still setting up and sound checking, but they had on a mix of reggae standards, which was great. Then the band took the stage and began to play, which was awesome. I was bummed that I had been out all day and at that point was running out of steam. I really would like to have stayed longer than I did and hear more of the band. Bottom line, aside from the cover it's a great time if you're a reggae fan.
Awesome reggae and happy people! If you like a laid back place with great live music, go here!

I went there last night with my Girlfriend, after our not-so-good experience with Uberstein. As soon as we entered we were greeted by a lady in dreadlocks telling us to "Have fun, Brother!". There was no live band at the moment and the place was almost empty. Staff is very friendly and atmosphere relaxing. Obviously, there is Reggae music playing in the background. During our time spent there we've spotted only 1 group of douche bags in cub's outfits, but they left after 2 minutes. The place got more crowded before we left, so I assume that someone was going to be playing. I will definitely come back to see live Reggae!

There really aren't that many clubs that have excellent live reggae 7 nights a week, so I give the WILD HARE a full 5 stars. We went on a random weekend night and decided to check out the band after several drinks at Goose Island. Crucial Decision! The reggae was top notch. Definitely feeling the fellowship in that place... the vibes were Irie, the red stripe was flowing, and I might have even thrown back a few incredible hulks. All I'm saying is that the whole place was grooving hard. I smelled some funny smoke in the bathroom, and being a couple of the only white folks in the joint, we got some comments like "Damn, you dance pretty good for a white boy"... which really was awesome... ha! Go to the Wild Hare... but be careful, it will yield smiling, grooving, and a definite Irie state of mind.

One of the great music spots in the city, though in a strange location (why isnt it located closer to some West Indian communities?). Great music, can't wait til the day they have some Panamanian reggae. Wish it was more queer-friendly though, being in such close proximity to Boys Town.

I expect to add an extra star on my next visit. My constant lament with this place used to be the smoke! Oh the smoke! No, not that kind either! :-) The State of IL banned cigarette smoke which make my problems with Wild Hare disappear.  I honestly don't mind the cover charge. I am usually there because the band playing is one I want to see. I agree that the drinks are a tad over-priced but this is a function of the 'hood I would speculate. Yes I am letting Wild Hare get away with it. These are the only reasons you would go to Wild Hare. You love reggae, you want to dance and when thirsty and shocked by the sticker price there's water. -yes? Okay it is mostly because everytime I've been here, I have made it my business to meet the band members. Talked to Buju, Ziggy Marley (nice bloke), Beres Hammond.... enough name dropping though.

So this used to be one of my favorite spots, hence the 4 stars.  They've recently remodeled.  While there is more space now since the stage is pushed back, I miss the pics of all the reggae legends.  They've also changed their dress code; actually now they have one.  You used to be able to come in anything.  Not sure how this dresscode thing is gonna effect them when the Cubs start playing since people come straight from the game.  The staff is always friendly here.   If you prefer dancehall/hip-hop, come on Wednesday night.  They have a dj spinning some hot stuff on Wednesdays.  He's my friend!!!!  Too bad I can't remember his name. lol  Although it's rare that I actually pay the cover; for informational purposes it's $7 for women, $10 for men on Wednesdays.  They also have a college night once a month, I think it's the first Thursday. But the live music is awesome here as well.  Be prepared to be hot and sweaty when you leave because it gets SUPER crowded and you can't help but dance your butt off all night long.  I have so many memories of this place.  WOW!!!!  The crowd is also pretty cool, but be prepared for the men to try to dance all over you.  Just give them a mean look if you want and they'll go away! :-) Drinks aren't too expensive and you will feel them.  I've needed to call for a ride home plenty of times.  Check it out, have fun, and lose 5 pounds of sweat!!  Great times!!!

Yelp, yelp... I'm back.  I've been on a reviewing hiatus, but that doesn't mean that I haven't been getting out! I checked out the Wild Hare last night with a few friends who are definitely old school when it comes to their reggae.  Two very good bands played and there was definitely plenty of room to get your wind and grind on (my ankles still kill from all the dancing).  I didn't drink last night so I can't tell you about their prices or what not, but The music was great, and i had a lovely time.  There are a few unsavory types that I got hit on by, so be careful of that, ladies, but I guess that's kind of anywhere you go, no?  My only viable complaints are no coat check (which is ridiculous for Chicago winters...lucky me it was beautiful out yesterday and I just wore a wrap) and there is little seating for when you need to take a break from doing the butterfly.... If you have a little rasta in you from time to time, mos def, check, check it out.  Irie, Irie.

Maybe its not right to give a review 4 years later after having only been there once, but I LOVE reggae (don't know much about it except that it makes me very happy when I hear it!) and I don't know of many places that play it! The bands when I was there were great- such amazing energy! The no seating issue was the only problem I had with this place (definitely don't wear heels! I learned my lesson!)

The Hare has the best Reggae music in the city. There is usually a steep cover charge, but if you get there before the first band you can get in free (it will be very empty then also). The dance floor gets packed as the rum punches set in. The drinks are a bit pricey but the Red Stripes are reasonable and very good. Bring change to the restroom, because there is a ladies room attendant.

Good place to go and listen to some live reggae. Pretty diverse crowd. The only thing I hate about it is that it gets too smoky and the men are just prowling around the women ready to attack. The drinks are okay and its just a good option to get your reggae fixin.

This is the place to go for reggae in Chicago.  The crowd is diverse and dance-happy, especially after a few Red Stripes.  The bands are well-schooled and, at the same time, innovative. There is a cover on the weekends, but I believe there's a student discount with an ID. Seating is limited to stools that are taken away as the first band starts, leaving room for dancing, so wear comfortable shoes.
